events.originalText: The NASA space probe New Horizons flew by the trans-Neptunian object Arrokoth, making it the farthest object visited by a spacecraft.
events.subtitle: NASA
events.headline: NASA's New Horizons probe flies by farthest object, Arrokoth

events.originalText: A suicide bombing took place outside a Coptic Orthodox Church in Alexandria, Egypt, following a New Year service, killing 23 people.
events.subtitle: 2011 Alexandria bombing
events.headline: Suicide bombing outside Coptic Church in Alexandria kills 23

events.originalText: A suicide bomber killed 105 spectators at a volleyball game in the Lakki Marwat District of Pakistan.
events.subtitle: 2010 Lakki Marwat suicide bombing
events.headline: 105 killed in suicide bombing at volleyball game in Pakistan

events.originalText: Adam Air Flight 574 crashed into the sea off Polewali, Indonesia, killing all 102 people on board, when the pilots inadvertently disconnected the autopilot.
events.subtitle: Adam Air Flight 574
events.headline: Adam Air Flight 574 crashes in Indonesia, 102 dead

events.originalText: Argentinian physicist Juan Maldacena published a landmark paper initiating the study of AdS/CFT correspondence, which links string theory and quantum gravity.
events.subtitle: Juan Maldacena
events.headline: Physicist Juan Maldacena publishes paper on AdS/CFT correspondence

events.originalText: The People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan, which later helped the country become a republic, was founded.
events.subtitle: People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan
events.headline: People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan founded

events.originalText: The revised Thai criminal code came into force, strengthening the law on lèse-majesté in Thailand to include insult and treating it as a crime against national security.
events.subtitle: Lèse-majesté in Thailand
events.headline: Revised Thai criminal code strengthens law on lèse-majesté

events.originalText: World War II: In retaliation for the massacre of captured Americans by Waffen SS soldiers, U.S. Army personnel killed an estimated 80 Wehrmacht prisoners near Chenogne, Belgium.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Retaliation for massacre: U.S. Army kills 80 Wehrmacht prisoners

events.originalText: Second World War: The Luftwaffe launched Operation Bodenplatte in an attempt to cripple Allied air forces in the Low Countries.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Luftwaffe launches Operation Bodenplatte in Low Countries

events.originalText: Joseph Stalin's personal secretary, Boris Bazhanov, crossed the Iranian border and defected from the Soviet Union.
events.subtitle: Joseph Stalin
events.headline: Stalin's secretary defects from Soviet Union

events.originalText: Russia withdraws from its occupation of northwestern Iran, enabling a subsequent Ottoman invasion and massacres of Assyrians and Armenians.
events.subtitle: Sayfo
events.headline: Russia withdraws from occupation of northwestern Iran

events.originalText: The St. Petersburg–Tampa Airboat Line in the U.S. state of Florida became the first scheduled airline using a winged aircraft.
events.subtitle: St. Petersburg–Tampa Airboat Line
events.headline: St. Petersburg–Tampa Airboat Line becomes first scheduled airline

events.originalText: The immigration station on Ellis Island (pictured) in New York Harbor opened, and would process almost 12 million immigrants to the United States over the course of its existence.
events.subtitle: Ellis Island
events.headline: Ellis Island immigration station opens in New York Harbor

events.originalText: As a result of the lobbying efforts by the abolitionist movement (emblem pictured), the importation of slaves into the United States was officially banned, although slavery itself remained permitted.
events.subtitle: Abolitionism
events.headline: Importation of slaves into the U.S. officially banned

events.originalText: Italian astronomer Giuseppe Piazzi discovered the dwarf planet Ceres, naming it after the Roman goddess of agriculture and of motherly love.
events.subtitle: Giuseppe Piazzi
events.headline: Astronomer Giuseppe Piazzi discovers dwarf planet Ceres

events.originalText: Quasi-War: An American convoy of four merchant vessels escorted by a schooner was attacked by a squadron of armed barges manned by Haitians.
events.subtitle: Quasi-War
events.headline: American convoy attacked by Haitians during Quasi-War

events.originalText: The Times began publication in London as The Daily Universal Register.
events.subtitle: The Times
events.headline: The Times begins publication in London

events.originalText: American Revolutionary War: The town of Norfolk, Virginia, was burned and destroyed by the combined actions of British and Whig forces.
events.subtitle: American Revolutionary War
events.headline: Norfolk, Virginia, burned by British and Whig forces

events.originalText: The hymn "Amazing Grace" was probably first used in a prayer meeting in Olney, England, without the music familiar to modern listeners.
events.subtitle: Hymn
events.headline: Hymn 'Amazing Grace' first used in Olney, England

events.originalText: Bouvet Island in the South Atlantic Ocean, the most remote island in the world, was discovered by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier.
events.subtitle: Bouvet Island
events.headline: Bouvet Island discovered by French explorer

events.originalText: Having been pardoned by Eudokia Makrembolitissa, the regent of the Byzantine Empire, for attempting to usurp the throne, Romanos IV Diogenes married her to become Byzantine emperor.
events.subtitle: Eudokia Makrembolitissa
events.headline: Romanos IV Diogenes marries regent Eudokia Makrembolitissa

events.originalText: Galla Placidia was forced by her brother Honorius into marriage with his magister militum, Constantius III.
events.subtitle: Galla Placidia
events.headline: Galla Placidia forced into marriage with Constantius III
